citances.sentence: On 1 March 2007, shortly before his trial was to commence Mr Wotton lodged a complaint with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (as the Australian Human Rights Commission was then called). The complaint alleged, among other matters, that the arrest, charging and prosecution of Mr Wotton contravened or would contravene the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 (Cth). Mr Wotton sought an ex parte injunction under s 46PP of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act to restrain the holding of his criminal trial: Wotton v State of Queensland [2007] FCA 280. Those proceedings purported to be instituted as representative proceedings under Pt IVA of the Federal Court of Australia Act . In refusing the ex parte relief, Moore J noted that there had been considerable delay in the lodging of the complaint with the Commission: Wotton [2007] FCA 280 at [3] - [5]. His Honour said that he would express no view about whether those proceedings could have been brought as representative proceedings. Subsequently, at his trial Mr Wotton was convicted and sentenced to a term of imprisonment.
